information_requirement: Is an adversary capturing user credentials via keylogging on mobile devices? (PIR)

evidence.description: An application with keyboard functionality is present on a device, and its package name or developer signature is not on the corporate allowlist. Alternatively, an allowed keyboard app's binary hash or signature has changed from a known-good baseline.
data_sources: Mobile Device Management (MDM) Application Inventory Logs
evidence.nai: Corporate-managed mobile devices, BYOD devices with corporate profiles
evidence.action: 1. (Symbolic) Maintain an allowlist of approved keyboard applications, including package names, versions, and developer signatures. Continuously scan MDM application inventories. Generate a high-severity alert for any keyboard application not on the allowlist or whose developer signature does not match the approved record. 2. (Statistical) For all installed keyboard applications, calculate the prevalence across the device fleet. Any keyboard with a prevalence below a dynamic threshold (e.g., installed on fewer than 1% of devices or 3 absolute devices) should be flagged for review. Track the installation date and calculate the time-to-install delta for new keyboards; a sudden burst of installs for a rare keyboard is anomalous. 3. (ML) Develop a classification model (e.g., Random Forest) trained on application metadata (permissions requested, developer reputation, app store category, install source, age of developer account, user review sentiment). The model should predict the likelihood of an application being malicious. A keyboard application with a high maliciousness score, especially when combined with low prevalence, triggers a critical alert for immediate investigation.

evidence.description: An Android application is granted the 'android.permission.BIND_ACCESSIBILITY_SERVICE' permission, and the application is not on a pre-approved allowlist for this specific, high-risk permission or does not belong to a legitimate functional category like 'Accessibility Tool' or 'Password Manager'.
evidence.nai: Corporate-managed Android devices, BYOD Android devices with corporate profiles
evidence.action: 1. (Symbolic) From MDM permission logs, continuously monitor for the granting of 'BIND_ACCESSIBILITY_SERVICE'. Maintain an explicit allowlist of applications (e.g., approved password managers, corporate support tools) authorized to use this service. Alert immediately on any application not on the allowlist that is granted this permission. 2. (Statistical) For applications requesting 'BIND_ACCESSIBILITY_SERVICE', calculate the Shannon entropy of the full requested permissions set. Applications with an unusually high entropy score (requesting a wide, diverse range of permissions unrelated to their stated function) should be flagged. Compare the set of permissions to the baseline of other apps in the same category; a Jaccard distance greater than the 95th percentile for that category indicates a high-risk outlier. 3. (ML) Use an anomaly detection model (e.g., Isolation Forest) on the sequence of API calls made by an application after being granted accessibility services. Train the model on legitimate accessibility applications. Deviations from the learned normal behavior, such as file system access or network connections immediately following text input events ('TYPE_VIEW_TEXT_CHANGED'), should be scored as highly anomalous and generate an alert.

evidence.description: A mobile device initiates a recurring pattern of small, outbound network connections to a destination not associated with any legitimate, installed application. These connections are characterized by low data volume and consistent time intervals (heartbeating).
evidence.nai: Network egress points (e.g., corporate WiFi, VPN gateway), Mobile device network interfaces
evidence.action: 1. (Symbolic) Correlate network flow logs from mobile devices with threat intelligence feeds. Generate a high-severity alert for any connection from a mobile device to a known malicious IP address or domain, especially if the connection originates from an unrecognized application process. 2. (Statistical) From Zeek conn.log, group by source device IP. For each device, analyze outbound connections to a single destination. Flag destinations where the standard deviation of time deltas between consecutive connections is low (<1s) and the 95th percentile of outbound data volume ('orig_bytes') is low (<1KB). Correlate with Zeek dns.log; if the destination domain was registered within the last 30 days, escalate the alert priority. 3. (ML) Implement a time-series analysis model (e.g., LSTM) for each device's outbound traffic volume and connection frequency. An alert is generated when the model detects a significant anomaly, such as the emergence of a new, low-volume, periodic signal that deviates from the established baseline, which could indicate a keylogger C2 channel.
